body.p:
Christian 4th of March 1861,
To his Ex. Gov. Magoffin-
Dr Sir-

Jonathan Greer- has been convicted of Manslaughter by a Jury of Christian. He is a good Fine man, as I verily believe -- the circumstances of the case will be explained to you by Mr. Berry. They will I trust be sufficient for you. to exercise your executive clemency I am satisfied that his pardon will ^be^ greeted with great joy- by the very best people in his neighborhood & in the county --
I remain very faithfully your dutiful subject-
I concur fully in all Col Morris has said
I also concur fully in all Col Morris has Said

I have Examined the Contents endorsed by the distinguished Citizens whose names appear within and and fully concur with them- And will also add that a large number, if not a large majority of our Citizens believe Mr. Grear Justifiable in the lamentable deed which has resulted in his conviction_ The undersigned has been requainted with Mr. Grear for a quarter of a century and all that time he has had the reputation of a sober, orderly Citizen_ He is an old man; and should executive Clemency be exercised in his favor, the act would be kindly appreciated by many Citizens of one County ^&^ by a large circle of acquaintances & friends, but the Joy & delight the act would bring to a distressed wife & children it were unecessary to speak of- Respectfully & obediently yours-
